name: Retired, but still dangerous
description:
This is a Big Rig Iain concept deck. Having tinkered with something similar before already, I'm mostly publishing this because Thike wanted to see my take on his deck. Don't consider this finished, it's more of a template to further tune.

The most important thing when playing Iain is definitely not to get too greedy wanting to use his ability. It's not something that you should be planning to use, but rather it's something that alleviates the Criminal faction's difficulty to catch up once fallen behind.

Why Morning Star? Because it's awesome! The up-front cost might seem scary at first, but once you break Eli twice, you're on par with Corroder, and it only gets better after that. Breaking Hive once means you're only 1 credit behind a Corroder play, any more encounters are pure win. The memory cost is usually the biggest problem, which is why I'm using Zu (for additional synergy with the Link bit of the deck). Also, Datasuckers.

If I had two more influence, the card that would go in would be Donut Taganes, to combat Accelerated Shutdown decks and give me an option to go for denial-based play.

name: ICEing Up
description: WIP. Will be checking which money works well, and which doesn't.

name: Reworked, once more
Trash to Treasure v0.9
description:
The key focus here is to get out the strongest (most expensive) breakers early and as cheap as possible.

With a good hand you most likely will have an 8-9 cost breaker out on turn 2 with Retrieval Run.

Quality Time is rather essential as it tends to work well with Freelance Coding Contract in both getting a handful of programs in your heap and a decent pile of credits.

I am not too sure about Diesel. I have toyed with Replicator to get more copies of clone chip and Prepaid VoicePad. Also have considered Same Old Thing to get some easier copies of Indexing or Retrieval Run but I am still unsure if that will work the best.

name: Reworked, once more
Regionals Decklist LinCon Sweden - 2nd place (corp)
description:
Played at the LinCon regionals 30/5 2014 with 24 participants. Was played with 4 rounds of swiss and then top-8 double elimination. Finished first after the swiss (without a bye) at 14 prestige.

Went 5-2 during the tournament (3-1 in the swiss) where my only swiss loss was in a epic game against Noise where he managed to snag a last 2-pointer for the win in a major medium/demo run dig with no cards in hand or in his deck (if he had hit my last one-pointer instead it would have been my win since he was at 5 points).

The deck works really well if you expect a criminal-heavy meta but the shaper match-up is hard if they run a lot of recursion.

Mostly I like the card choices, but the Braintrusts should probably be Medical Breakthrough instead. Yagura should probably be swapped out for something with End the Run, perhaps a Wall of Thorns or the third Quandary. ICE choices are limited since the deck runs so little economy and has no slots for additional economy.

name: Regionals Decklist LinCon Sweden - 2nd place (runner)
description:
Played at the LinCon regionals 30/5 2014 with 24 participants. Was played with 4 rounds of swiss and then top-8 double elimination. Finished first after the swiss (without a bye) at 14 prestige.

The deck worked really well during the day with a final record of 6-1 (4-0 in the swiss). Security Testing is amazing, and I feel two is the right number. I continue to be unimpressed with Inside Job and will probably cut the last one as well. Really want to find room for the second e3, it makes the HB Glacier match-up a lot easier if you don't get a strong enough start.

Unfortunatly I didn't get to snag any Shi-Kyu during my games but considering how jinteki-heavy the meta was I still think the Data Dealer is worth a slot.

name: RP Test
Jinteki - Yakuza Style v2
description:
Idea of the deck: I just wanted to make it fun and painful to run

I played this deck in a tournament. I only won once with it on 4 games, but I lost my last just because I forgot about my House of Knives. In all games, the runners had a really good time since this is a challenging corp without being a turtle corp. I could feel their anxiety at every run and the "Will I die?!" in their eyes, priceless!

I am not fan of Celebrity Gift, but to tease the runner into coming to get the agenda in my hand (Future Perfect), that was really cool.

Enjoy :-D

name: Harmonious ICE Age
description: Trying to make a 6-agenda deck. I'm a little worried about how porous the ICE is, but there should be room to grow here. I think I'm gonna run this at my FLGS next week and see how it does.

name: Noise's Stone Mill
description: Standard Noise mill machine with the addition of Capstone. Its running 3 of all the essential pieces of the machine for consistency. Once you have your machine running, trash the extra resources with capstone to cycle them and get your viruses out faster. Levy it all back in and go again. This deck does nothing but make money so the single Crypsis will get you into the archives for the glory run. Any suggestions and ideas are much appreciated.

name: Knight Classes V1.1
description:
Deep Red is 1 influence. The professor can spare 1 influence. That was the concept.

What it became was using an insane amount of draw power and recursion to get exactly what you need, when you need it.

Diesel, Quality Time, and Self-Modifying Code get you what you need. Clone Chip and Scavenge keep them there. Test Run can do both of those things.

Central Breakers plus a few extra. Knight can pop in where you need him. Parasite and Datasucker kill things. Other programs provide Econ.

Largely an experiment but I look forward to developing it further. Hoping for some feedback.

name: Arrested Development V0.4
description: A slightly older version of my program trashing Weyland deck.

name: The sky is the limit
description: an NBN FA sketch

name: Planned assaults on Dinosaurs
description:
I took a lot of inspiration from the Chronos Protocol winning decklist Dinomite for this deck. It combines the best events to be used with both planned assault and same old thing but also has the backup plan of quickly building one of the best rigs in the game.

Some changes I've considered are:

+2 Plascrete Carapace

-2 Public Sympathy

This is partly a meta choice and partly just due to me not wanting to include a card that is almost more common than sure gamble at this point when I first laid out this deck list. More security from the flatline is traded for more options at any given time.

Please Let me know what you think and suggest any changes. I've only played this a few times and done well. I had some trouble with Jinteki PE though and thought about changing Deus X for Net Shield but I think that's just a knee jerk reaction that would not serve me well in a tournament.

name: Arrested Development V0.5
description: Newest version of my Program trashing Weyland deck, which includes Flare and Power Shutdown to also try and get at hardware. I tried to free up influence to put in some Aggressive Secretaries, as they're the only non-sentry non-ICE card I can use to trash programs (namely, the sentry breaker if they have one out). I didn't get much. I also tried to add more ice. Any suggestions would be lovely.

name: Fast advance jinteki
Destroy All Planets 4.0
description: Destroy all the runner scum's pathetic breakers and enact my agendas with impunity.

name: First Clone deck
No Click Tuesday (Version 2.0)
description:
Very click taxing deck with Eli 1.0, Ichi 1.0, Enigma, Viktor 1.0, Hourglass, and Heimdall 2.0. Runners are often left with the bad choice to spend precious clicks to break subroutines (and not have enough clicks to run on remotes), lose credits (and not have enough to trash income or upgrades), or suffer subroutines (which can include brain damage).

Once the first Agenda is scored, it becomes increasingly difficult for the Runner to run on Remote Servers, even with Bypass events. Add Ruhr Valley and Caprice Nisei into the mix and force the Runner to pay the tax all over again >:).

Since running remotes are costly, high trash values like PAD Campaign are often left unchecked. Sundew, Celebrity Gift, and Hedge Fund are enough to keep the income flowing to pay for some of the more nasty ICE like Heimdall 2.0 or Komainu.

This deck is not entirely meant to flatline, but it can if the Runner is not careful. It keeps Runners who stick to running Central Servers on their toes.

name: Income Tax Season - Season 1 First Place
description:
I brought this deck to OMG Games' season 1 tournament on the 31st of May. We did 4 rounds of Swiss, and this deck won 3/4 of its games. The idea is that it is obviously taxing, and all of the agendas cost credits to steal.

In the agenda department, there isn't much of a choice with the selection, but Utopia Fragment will eventually take the place of a Future Perfect. The Interns will then become Fast Tracks, and the deck will be even stronger. Anyway, I lost one game with it (my only loss that day), and it was honestly due to terrible piloting. An earlier build made it to top 8 in another season 1 tourney, but the ICE has been changed greatly since.

Last note: The 1-of Grim did so much work, it was worth running along side NAPD.

name: Economics 101 - Season 1 First Place
description:
I brought this deck to OMG Games' season 1 tournament on the 31st of May. We did 4 rounds of Swiss, and this deck won 4/4 of its games.

Lately, Netrunner has been too taxing for me to keep up with, and my Andy deck just couldn't make enough money to win games competitively. I decided to switch it up and try click less economy, with a bunch of burst economy, and it worked out great. It won every game that day, and I was never locked out or shutdown, so that was nice. Its not too interesting of a deck, but I thought I would post it, since it did so well. Gaining 7 credits at the start of my turn was pretty fun.

name: Division of Fringe Applications
description: This Jinteki deck has been tested online and offline. The main focus is on its ability to create advancement tokens. It uses them for strengthening ICE, generating credits via GRNDL Refinery and Commercialization and scoring agendas via Trick of Light. Several sources of net damage ensure that there is a constant threat on runner to lose critical cards if not being flatlined.

name: Solutions Provider
description: This Professor deck has been tested online and offline. Its capability to provide a suitable (program) solution for almost any situation is quite rewarding for skilled players.

name: Weyland Glacier Test
